title: PTD Today — Media

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award–winning podcast Where the Internet Lives and examines the intersection of AI, data and creativity—specifically how AI empowers artists—within the unseen world of data centers. It frames creative AI work in the context of the infrastructure that supports it.
bullets: No transcript available; description only.
Film ties to Season 5 of the podcast Where the Internet Lives.
Focuses on how AI empowers artists and creative work.
Situated around the 'unseen world' of data centers and supporting infrastructure.
Uses hashtags: #WhereTheInternetLives #AI #Data #Creativity
takeaways: Based on the description's focus on AI and data centers: anticipate growth in AI-driven creative workloads and plan capacity and power provisioning accordingly.
Higher-density AI workloads can raise cooling and power-density needs—review cooling strategies and rack-level power capabilities.
Stakeholders should prioritize renewables and on-site storage to support sustainability messaging and manage intermittent supply as creative AI services scale.
Consider edge or distributed deployment for latency-sensitive creative tools, which can influence site selection and network planning.
Monitor hardware supply chains and demand for AI accelerators, as increased creative AI adoption can drive needs for components tied to critical minerals.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno (Product Manager, Cloud Networking at Google) explains how AI-aware networking—using GKE Inference Gateway and Cloud Load Balancing—optimizes AI inference by routing on inference-specific signals (KV cache utilization, queue depth) rather than traditional CPU metrics. The approach adds prefix/body-based routing, LoRA adapter awareness and Service Extensions (network-level API/guardrail insertion) to reduce cold starts, maximize GPU utilization, lower latency and cut wasted compute.
bullets: Traditional networking and round-robin load balancers miss GPU congestion because CPU metrics don’t reflect inference load.
GKE Inference Gateway and AI-aware load balancing use specialized metrics (KV cache utilization, queue depth) to identify least-loaded replicas.
Prefix caching and shadow copies let the gateway reuse prefill computations to reduce GPU work and latency for common prompts.
Body-based routing and LoRA-awareness enable routing to the correct model/adapter instance without complex topologies.
Service Extensions let organizations insert API management and AI guardrails at the network edge to sanitize requests before they hit GPUs.
takeaways: Better GPU saturation and fewer cold starts can lower overall power draw per inference and improve data center energy efficiency.
Routing that reduces wasted GPU cycles (via cache reuse and edge sanitization) can cut compute costs and avoid unnecessary thermal load or peak power events.
Network-layer guardrails reduce wasted inference workload, helping control OPEX and reduce marginal energy and cooling demands.
Unified, network-aware routing simplifies deployment and can reduce operational complexity for large AI fleets—helpful for capacity planning and asset utilization.
Edge sanitization and routing choices can influence when and how workloads run, which matters for scheduling demand, on-site backup power sizing, and integration with renewables or storage.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this video showcases the open-world martial arts RPG "Where Winds Meet" running with NVIDIA RTX features and DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation enabled. It emphasizes visual quality with #RTXOn and credits footage to @DigitalDreamsyt.
bullets: Open-world martial arts RPG: Where Winds Meet
Features NVIDIA DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation
Showcases #RTXOn visuals (ray tracing enabled)
Footage credited to @DigitalDreamsyt
No transcript available in the provided content
takeaways: DLSS 4 Multi Frame Generation signals growing use of AI inference on GPUs, implying higher specialized compute demand for gaming and cloud-rendering workloads.
RTX (real-time ray tracing) workloads increase GPU power draw and thermal requirements—relevant for capacity planning in GPU clusters and gaming server farms.
Frame-generation tech can change where compute is performed (client vs cloud); infrastructure planners should assess whether to invest in endpoint-capable GPUs or centralized render farms.
Expect episodic spikes in GPU energy consumption around major demos/releases—coordinate renewables, storage, or demand-response strategies to manage peak loads.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video emphasizes the importance of anticipating the remaining life of aging steam turbine rotors and outlines next steps plant operators can take. It frames rotor end‑of‑life assessment as central to steam plant reliability and points viewers to GE Vernova for more information and support.
bullets: Focuses on assessing an aging steam turbine rotor’s remaining life and planning next actions.
Positions rotor EOL management as the backbone of steam plant reliability.
Directs viewers to GE Vernova resources for detailed guidance (link provided).
Promotes GE Vernova’s role in electrification and decarbonization.
Includes channel subscription and social links for further contact.
takeaways: Prioritize rotor end‑of‑life assessments to avoid unexpected outages that could impact grid or data center uptime.
Use OEM guidance (e.g., GE Vernova) to inform repair, refurbishment or replacement timing and minimize operational risk.
Integrate rotor lifecycle planning into maintenance and capital schedules to preserve plant reliability and critical-load availability.
Engage with vendor resources early to align turbine lifecycle decisions with broader decarbonization or grid flexibility goals.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this KPMG ON AIR episode reviews how the luxury goods market is transforming — with a shift from ownership to experiences, rising ESG expectations, and the growth of “affordable luxury.” Speakers highlight Poland’s growing but fragmented luxury market, trends such as personalization, Gen Z preference for experiences, luxury tourism and hotels, the art market, and a future shaped by AI alongside craftsmanship.
bullets: Experience-first luxury, personalization, and “affordable luxury” are reshaping demand.
ESG and responsible-luxury (e.g., eco-leathers, certifications) are gaining prominence.
Poland: market still growing domestically despite global slowdowns; fragmented landscape.
Luxury hospitality, tourism and art markets are notable growth areas within Poland.
Future drivers include AI-enabled services plus a continued role for craftsmanship and human experiences.
takeaways: Rising luxury tourism and premium hospitality in Poland can increase local peak electricity demand—plan capacity and resilience for hotels, spas and premium coastal developments.
AI-driven personalization and digital experiences imply higher compute needs; expect growing data-center capacity and power-density requirements for luxury brands and platforms.
ESG certifiability and sustainable materials shift supplier choices—renewables, storage and traceable supply chains (including critical-minerals transparency) become procurement priorities.

Broader ‘affordable luxury’ adoption expands customer-facing electrified services (hospitality systems, EV charging, on-site edge compute), suggesting need for distributed energy resources and site-level backup.
Emphasis on brand experiences and film/hospitality tie-ins may favor edge data and low-latency networks at venues—consider localized generation, microgrids and UPS solutions for continuity.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video emphasizes that since 1927 PJM Interconnection has made reliability its primary mission. It invites viewers to learn how PJM works to ensure electricity is available when you need it.
bullets: Highlights PJM’s long-standing focus on reliability dating back to 1927.
Positions PJM as the regional operator responsible for making sure electricity is there when needed.
Framed as an explainer about how PJM works to maintain reliable service.
Aimed at informing stakeholders and the public about PJM’s reliability role.
takeaways: For grid planners: reaffirm that regional operators like PJM are central to maintaining system reliability—coordinate planning and interconnection requests accordingly.
For data center operators: prioritize engagement with PJM and regional reliability guidance when assessing site power risk and backup strategies.
For renewables/storage project developers: monitor PJM communications and processes that affect interconnection and reliability integration.
For asset managers and utilities: use PJM reliability resources as inputs to transmission, substation, and resilience investments.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, power systems must balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. Hitachi Energy positions digital technologies at the core of grid modernization to improve stability, reduce downtime and optimize performance across the network.
bullets: Emphasis on balancing reliability, flexibility and efficiency as capacity grows for the energy transition.
Digital technologies are central to Hitachi Energy's approach to grid modernization.
Digitalization aims to improve system stability and reduce operational downtime.
Optimization of performance is targeted 'at every level' of the power grid.
Solutions intended to support integration of expanded capacity (e.g., renewables and storage).
takeaways: Prioritize digital-first grid upgrades to boost stability and minimize downtime for critical assets.
Design capacity expansion with flexibility and efficiency in mind to accommodate more renewables and storage.
Use digital optimization tools to improve asset performance across substations and broader networks.
When selecting vendors, look for end-to-end digital capabilities that support reliability and operational optimization.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy frames industrial resilience around energy efficiency, process optimization and digital integration. The company emphasizes partnering with customers to deploy smarter systems that boost productivity, reliability and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Resilience built on energy efficiency, process optimization and digital integration.
Hitachi Energy partners with customers and other organizations to implement solutions.
Focus on smarter systems to improve productivity across industrial operations.
Reliability and sustainability are called out as core outcomes of these systems.
Call-to-action to discover more via the provided Hitachi Energy link.
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency and process-optimization projects to strengthen operational resilience.
Require digital integration (monitoring, control, analytics) when specifying new grid or data‑center power assets to unlock reliability and productivity gains.
Engage vendors and partners who offer integrated, end‑to‑end solutions rather than point products to accelerate deployment and measurable sustainability outcomes.
Frame procurement and upgrades around measurable reliability and sustainability KPIs to align investments with operational goals.
